elements.2211.03271_1198161b4d6665c9565e25734440e: I summarize and streamline the results of recent modeling of the orbital evolution

elements.2211.03271_3608ea12ddf330c9801e4053a493c: The Great March Comet of 1843, a member of Population

elements.2211.03271_30a466e5c006c62811c4b9abcf1c2: I. The additions to the Kreutz system proposed as part of the new model are the daylight comets of AD

elements.2211.03271_7234dea4fc0c064d0b775f77d0eda: Kreutz sungrazers in the coming decades is predicted.
elements.2211.03271_c5b1b078de9334750b0444952fe18: Recent introduction of a new model for the orbital evolution of the Kreutz system of sungrazing comets (Seka
elements.2211.03271_fd646af551b50d2318e423505ec31: nina 2021a; hereafter referred to as Paper
elements.2211.03271_f6f697bc4e8b0a9aaee5071d05698: 1) was necessitated by significant developments in the past 15
elements.2211.03271_cf822812bc401fa17b69943ba9c62: years, which made major parts of the previous models, including the two-superfragment model (Sekanina 2002; Seka
elements.2211.03271_32fe79d4e77b74c1822b35c822bce: Among the developments, the most important event was the arrival of the naked-eye sungrazer Lovejoy (C/2011
elements.2211.03271_25e566bc5d33ad4e8f36b38febcb0: W3), whose orbit defied Marsden's (1989) expanded classification of the Kreutz comets into three populations
elements.2211.03271_d58e0419b63e0b6c13a372ffec2c3: Chodas (2012) referred to comet Lovejoy as a member of a new population
elements.2211.03271_32b3ac7f0d1252d5fcddb9e24d681: III, a designation adopted in Paper
elements.2211.03271_46cf07fcdb3efdc689fd2fe060fe5: The new model is based on two stipulations, not employed in the earlier models
elements.2211.03271_68ebe4c1642085364b07818bebc20: One is the progenitor in shape of a contact binary, consisting of two lobes of comparable dimensions connected with a neck
elements.2211.03271_6e2c97c9ec19ecae9cfd1dec14056: The progenitor's splitting into the separate lobes (and, simultaneously or subsequently, the neck) is much more plausible than the breakup of a nearly spherical nucleus into two halves through its center, the scenario tolerated in the two-superfragment model (Sekanina
elements.2211.03271_2d5c5ef6ca21a02f7e3c69df98059: Chodas 2004); a contact binary also emerges as the apparently rather common figure among cometary nuclei and Kuiper Belt objects (e.g., Sierks et al.
elements.2211.03271_e5f45e13f4e063f558b216189cf87: My second stipulation was that most of the surviving mass of Lobe
elements.2211.03271_60654270cd4c1c5614f53b6575398: I was contained in the Great March Comet of 1843 or C/1843
elements.2211.03271_6627af59e1566c1234c42d1a6a87b: D1, the intrinsically brightest known fragment of Population
elements.2211.03271_1ca7458e00d2f67eb0a063c76f65c: I, and most of the surviving mass of Lobe
elements.2211.03271_2c8e89fb06ffa4ae35989b9849450: II in the Great September Comet of 1882 or C/1882
elements.2211.03271_2c4dd0483252f28ca4b17fd2c9b7a: R1, intrinsically the brightest known fragment of Population
elements.2211.03271_dd1525074ec2f9ede8bd202b7bfcc: The orbital distance that separated the two masses, gradually increasing with time, was in the 19th century equivalent to a time difference of merely 39.5
elements.2211.03271_3d2eb9ef47a3471d4995de7e0b857: yr in perihelion time, a measure of the young age of the Kreutz system
elements.2211.03271_dca36168312026c73c2941ced46e5: This constraint effectively eliminated all scenarios that involved 5th
elements.2211.03271_4eb7325f526b79d40e609ec24603f: century comets as members of the Kreutz system because they would have implied orbital periods much too short to fit the arrival times of the two 19th
elements.2211.03271_45937e96fb0c1133a3a09aba7e408: Another recent development was the detection in Paper
elements.2211.03271_cfe4d1c0d95a010838bfe0bc3f889: 1 of as many as nine populations of sungrazers that are making up the Kreutz system
elements.2211.03271_fad9acbab1b196e22489d12e79024: This major result was obtained by processing Marsden's gravitational orbital elements of the SOHO Kreutz sungrazers (Section
elements.2211.03271_1ecc8d1e3bafb60724235d5fa5c4d: 2) and is understood in the context of cascading fragmentation:
elements.2211.03271_58c0e5f71e0e3a5bc385219d0af2f: the initial breakup was followed by a number of events of secondary splitting
elements.2211.03271_bff8e6b8415502101b6b60bed6f8d: The account and results of the new model are below summarized and streamlined with the aim to benefit the reader
elements.2211.03271_9d1597110c60d399600da79cb43a2: The problem of systematic trends in the gravitational orbital elements of the SOHO sungrazers was explored in great detail on several particular objects by Sekanina
elements.2211.03271_0e4763ff558b9dbd45f117ac71428: The most troublesome were the systematic positional deviations of the SOHO sungrazers' lines of apsides from the fixed position of the line of apsides of the naked-eye Kreutz comets
elements.2211.03271_a465303b5cb50148887a778de3f91: The deviations, apparent in the plots of the inclination and perihelion latitude against the longitude of the ascending node, were shown to be effects of the normal component of the nongravitational acceleration, while a set of select data of higher accuracy in Paper
elements.2211.03271_d5a22d9ab14e0e457a106d65d73f8: 1 revealed the structure of the system of SOHO Kreutz sungrazers to be much more complex than earlier thought
elements.2211.03271_213fa4f840d4efbeb39bce02aa47a: A further, not yet fully examined test, a potential relationship between the longitude of the ascending node and the perihelion distance, is a subject of the present paper.

elements.2211.03271_85f2f8e023007f4d03fa14c76c9c1: Marsden computed sets of approximate parabolic gravitational orbital elements for more than 1500 Kreutz sungrazers detected in the coronagraphic images of the SOHO space observatory between 1996 and 2010
elements.2211.03271_0b8cace661d39f9b86b98ee4afc61: The orbits are mostly in Marsden
elements.2211.03271_3ab3aa64a38d04004a9f357344fba: Williams (2008), for the objects that arrived during 2008
elements.2211.03271_548c0f4395d11d3b8e48dda9a386e: I refer to these sets of elements as
elements.2211.03271_215c0dc3de85162ef5df52c522e55: to distinguish them from the sets of
elements.2211.03271_c1e55958659d6fe56fa0cd73c6110: The difference is significant, as the SOHO sungrazers were subjected to an appreciable sublimation-driven force ignored by Marsden
elements.2211.03271_f19dd06b6cc59f73d7077d07f2645: The magnitude of this acceleration, directed
elements.2211.03271_3b3367734393de946c7f8f0d614fd: essentially in the direction normal to the orbital plane, was in extreme cases nearly comparable to the Sun's gravitational acceleration
elements.2211.03271_315bcfa0cec11ae1f5d7bc3f09695: The computation of the true orbit is time consuming, because the parameter
elements.2211.03271_b9c5d4d3a0a54171f48ac356b1556: of the normal component of the nongravitational acceleration had to be determined iteratively by forcing the standard position of the line of apsides, as illustrated by Sekanina

elements.2211.03271_d0662a1ffedd9e7b8b4e22fe97734: , presented for the 1500 SOHO Kreutz sungrazers in Figure

elements.2211.03271_ec05825016b266b78121c6f10fadc: Because the pixel size of the C3 coronagraph is about five times larger than the pixel size of the C2 coronagraph, an obvious way to improve the quality of the
elements.2211.03271_9fa7b4b7aba3feeeb0cfdc96c0301: plot was to restrict the data set to the objects whose nominal orbits were computed exclusively from the C2 images

elements.2211.03271_f7ecda591565295e63d66fe32d736: 1, supported by the naked-eye, Solwind (P78-1), and Solar Maximum Mission (SMM) objects, strong evidence has been assembled for a brand new investigation of the process of cascading fragmentation of the Kreutz system's progenitor.
elements.2211.03271_48ff913a1aa07f014b14207cfb260:
\begin{figure*}[ht]
\vspace{-0.45cm}
\hspace{-0.25cm}
\centerline{
\scalebox{0.79}{
\includegraphics{f2_dwarf.ps}}} % FIGURE 2 = Figure 1 of Paper 1
\vspace{-7.3cm}
\caption{Plot of the nominal latitude of perihelion, $B_\pi$, as a function of the
nominal longitude of the ascending node, $\Omega$ (equinox J2000), for the 193 dwarf
Kreutz sungrazers imaged in 1997--2010 exclusively with the C2 coronagraph on board
the SOHO Space Observatory; their gravitational orbits were computed by Marsden.  The
data points cluster fairly tightly along a set of straight lines of a constant slope of
\mbox{$dB_\pi/d\Omega = +0.28$} and refer to one of {\it nine\/} sungrazer populations.
Each line crosses the standard perihelion latitude of the population (Table~2) at a
point whose abscissa determines the respective population's {\it true\/} nodal longitude
(i.e., corrected for effects of the nongravitational acceleration).  In the order of
decreasing true nodal longitude, the populations are Pre-I, Pe, I, Ia, II, IIa, III,
IIIa, and IV, as depicted in the plot; Population~Pe is a side branch of Population~I.
All members of a population are plotted with the same symbol; the
exception is Population IIa, whose members with anomalously small perihelion distances,
IIa{\boldmath $^{\!\star}\!$}, are identified by symbols that differ from the symbols
for the remaining members.  The position of the {\it true\/} longitude of the ascending
node is for each population highlighted by an oversized circled star.  Some data points,
which were overlapping any of these major symbols or were contributing to one of
awkward-looking local clumps, were for the sake of clarity either removed or
slightly shifted along the slope of the fitting lines. (Reproduced from
Paper~1.){\vspace{0.7cm}}}
\end{figure*}
elements.2211.03271_a7f83a70d5b5045c8e7bab9132792: Nuclear Splitting:Separation Velocities and Perturbed Orbits of Fragments.Populations and Clusters
elements.2211.03271_4245cacbfe4638b7eb18abcb0e77b: Cometary nuclei fragment by a variety of forces
elements.2211.03271_8d17aa0ba1f5ac19381eb00ac70c2: Sungrazers split at or near perihelion by the Sun's tidal force
elements.2211.03271_c1a6482bb9c000fbe16613f18d014: This mechanism was in the past so popular that until recently all sungrazers were thought to break up exclusively in the immediate proximity of the Sun, in spite of the fact that efforts to explain the orbital evolution of the Kreutz system in this fashion met with formidable difficulties and were never successful.
elements.2211.03271_c9c81181aa08d861c6ad35e7bfc2f: On the other hand, it is well known that comets fairly often split far from the Sun and planets, and there is no reason why the sungrazers should do otherwise
elements.2211.03271_4e5f0bdc7fd7b83a136dcc7733d6f: Some 20 years ago I proposed (Sekanina 2002) that a Kreutz comet can fragment at any point of its orbit about the Sun and that the fragmentation process has cascading nature
elements.2211.03271_b89661bd9a3b8b057b8a940bbc346: This is of key importance because it turns out that the new orbit, in which a fragment ends up after breaking off from its sungrazing parent, depends dramatically on the orbital location of the event
elements.2211.03271_fd4447108c8bd8fa432d9cced9a59: When the breakup occurs at or near perihelion, the fragment's separation velocity
elements.2211.03271_37a397046bb0ae752ba899bbb916f: possibly of rotational origin and typically not exceeding a few meters per second
elements.2211.03271_7106a136dc6531471f93fa6aac716: affects almost exclusively the period of the new orbit, the difference compared to the parent's orbit reaching as much as several hundred years; the aphelion distance does of course change accordingly
elements.2211.03271_eeb7ab138f18ca78a80c17d877ba5: On the other hand, when the breakup takes place near aphelion (say, near
elements.2211.03271_af9196e77a5df840aff440b7f63b7: AU from the Sun), significantly affected are (i)
elements.2211.03271_4c578675625e084a39e9ac2727026: the angular elements by the normal component of the separation velocity, shifting by more than 10
elements.2211.03271_982793eaf5ece354b3a52c55fbcec: the perihelion distance by the transverse component, changing by a few tenths of the solar radius, so that the fragment's perihelion point may get below the surface of the photosphere
elements.2211.03271_e1aa7a66e13a439db2b803f64e977: Conversely, it is impossible for a Kreutz fragment to end up in an orbit whose period differs from the orbit of its parent by more than several days following an event occurring at or very close to aphelion; and it is equally impossible for a fragment to end up in an orbit whose angular elements and perihelion distance differ from those of its parent by any nontrivial amounts in an event taking place at or very close to perihelion
elements.2211.03271_a01657317cbd42e8dac7a53c8d755: Fragments generated by tidal disruption of a sungrazer are expected to end up in orbits with dramatically different periods even if they should acquire no differential momenta at breakup
elements.2211.03271_3e7dc6583858db37cb693146c053d: This is so because, in general, the centers of mass of the fragments are at the time located at slightly different heliocentric distances (Figure
elements.2211.03271_218de712d577c1be49bbe3abe95a0: 4) but have the same orbital velocity:
elements.2211.03271_f43514f50ac644151df481b7f17d2: the fragment farther from the Sun has to get into a greater orbit, with a longer period
elements.2211.03271_63667161793857ec76b01075decdb: If the heliocentric distance of the parent sungrazer at the time of fragmentation is
elements.2211.03271_e779aa2b160642fdf4a00fc5bd310: (at or near perihelion) and the difference in the radial distances between a fragment and the parent is
elements.2211.03271_4d64a0ceafa9f307c3d9c405f1aa3: , is related to the parent's orbital period,
elements.2211.03271_728bee9752ae913bb1c5b85a8218c: Kracht 2022; hereafter referred to as Paper
elements.2211.03271_5e60e84d65ce431d9f540167ec85e: where the orbital periods are in years, while
elements.2211.03271_a327e1f9e70734bc75f0d6445ff89: For example, a fragment separating at perihelion from a sungrazer whose perihelion distance is 1.5
elements.2211.03271_4f0bcc729a8fd0079eff29471b09b: yr ends up in an orbit whose orbital period is almost exactly 900
elements.2211.03271_205fdd9a12cb8536d7412d2d74a45: yr when the fragment's center of mass at the breakup is 5
elements.2211.03271_42a77ab4f3e959f08e6f6285ee458: km farther from the Sun than the parent's center of mass
elements.2211.03271_f0cb6fb5e78ebe5bfa96cb1486cda: This effect is marginal or trivial for all comets other than sungrazers
elements.2211.03271_6667173bba6a1e063af6a7f4ed81d: Another peculiar property of the Kreutz sungrazers is their anomalously low orbital velocity at aphelion, of about 20
elements.2211.03271_8a5dc62666bc52891fda8e0c83439: As a result, a separation velocity of a few meters per second could cause a fragment's orbital velocity to differ by more than 10
elements.2211.03271_2635d714b18009faf22572cbc2e40: percent from the parent's, a sizable relative change that implies a major orbit transformation
elements.2211.03271_efebdef4040b60f1a5ebcadb6beff: And if fragmentation events should be distributed randomly in time, their occurrence at large heliocentric distance is strongly favored.
elements.2211.03271_0b57ff62b943781877eb1b2dc6628: From the preceding it follows that fragments given birth in breakups of parent fragments in close proximity of perihelion became members of the same population but different clusters, whereas products of fragmentation events in proximity of aphelion became members of the same clusters but different populations
elements.2211.03271_d7e1c081395234188a05902adaa34: The Great September Comet of 1882 and comet Ikeya-Seki (C/1965
elements.2211.03271_b62a1c85d83edf06639945b065fe3: S1) present an example of two members of the same population that arrived at perihelion 83
elements.2211.03271_dd186fb3e47d379860b052efe8f20: yr apart, while the sungrazers Pereyra (C/1963
elements.2211.03271_f0bf86507614abca24f1725594bf0: K1) offer an example of three members of the same cluster that arrived at perihelion within seven years of one another, but belonged to Populations
elements.2211.03271_650143cd51bf2c141ab54d46e6592: The bottom line is that the spread among the SOHO Kreutz sungrazers in the longitude of the ascending node (a total of 66
elements.2211.03271_1f98f0bc159c38c8063a4d0d603e9: ) and in the other angular elements, apparent from Table
elements.2211.03271_588239c801c1df9199701d6a97680: be explained by recurring fragmentation at or near perihelion
elements.2211.03271_e2383c18062aecea6b3ad101ac1df: On the other hand, it was shown in Paper
elements.2211.03271_ff8b74e2d609bc3525866cad8b3a9: that the contact-binary model offers a self-consistent solution to the problem, fitting the observed data on the Kreutz system.
elements.2211.03271_b0440fb721987c583c141bb81e295: The main features of the model are chronologically summarized in the following subsections, which describe issues related, respectively, to (i)
elements.2211.03271_da5dc8ade837e2caa181ba6356fba: the primary (initial) breakup into the two lobes (and the neck); (iii)
elements.2211.03271_34b09baa908f1340da53ad61b87c3: the arrival of the first-generation fragments to perihelion; (v)
elements.2211.03271_020367834f9026bf79647154e9578: the arrival of the second- and third-generation fragments to perihelion; (vi)
elements.2211.03271_16e4b4d7c290ebc971250083e06c6: tidal fragmentation and dispersal of fragments, including the SOHO dwarf sungrazers; and (vii)
elements.2211.03271_addb71cc63f9cb0d76a70c21dd56b: issues behind the major overhaul of the old hypotheses and the model properties that withstood the challenges of new evidence.
elements.2211.03271_45d95c93a02eb3795739b45b75be8: of the Kreutz system in the recently introduced model was Aristotle's comet
elements.2211.03271_699712d445e96517a96f20886d2b6: The time of its appearance is usually given as (ca.) 372

elements.2211.03271_9c30211ed6b20edb30d13a539e2d9: Before I address the time relationship of the Achaea earthquake, I compare Aristotle's description with the story written by Diodorus Siculus about three centuries later

elements.2211.03271_3dc30e077b49726842a6e917fe101: , a divine portent foretold the loss of [Lacedaemonians'] empire; for there was seen in the heavens during the course of many nights a great blazing torch which was named from its shape a `flaming beam,' and a little later
elements.2211.03271_93fb9c611e3a7786b790738a8e555: the Spartans were defeated in a great battle and irretrievably lost their supremacy.
elements.2211.03271_32c6b0a0c8ba82532516ca3bcc0e4: The first part of this text is in glaring contradiction to Aristotle's account, which obviously ought to be preferred
elements.2211.03271_9fc35c758d06213120c2339c99859: Yet, one should ask why the conflict? The answer appears to be furnished by the rest of Diodorus' narrative
elements.2211.03271_6e0426c20e7cdd7bac33b0b6aa17f: The reference is to the Battle of Leuctra, which was fought on 6 July 371
elements.2211.03271_0d478c575f4bbfd5e03368b9b1d6a: BC and which Spartans lost to Boeotians led by Thebans
elements.2211.03271_bcbf89cb9c09d658d9dbc5517b3b4: Moving the sighting of the comet forward by one year, it was by that amount of time closer to the time of the battle, preceding it by 4
elements.2211.03271_ba28cdb5a080372596718288f6638: That of course made the comet a much more relevant portent
elements.2211.03271_bc443fc3a9053c2f3fed91c6baa17: In any case, Diodorus offered no good reason for correcting Aristotle! Now on the issue of the time that Aristotle assigned to the Achaean cataclysmic earthquake that engulfed the city-states of Helike (submerged by a tsunami) and Boura (collapsed and caved in)
elements.2211.03271_e5ffa4b0c2cd148961ca62cc6e23b: The universally adopted time for the earthquake has been the winter of 373

elements.2211.03271_ea195696bdddb66a883df1a57ea0b: Given that the battle was in the summer and the earthquake in the winter, the statement makes no sense

elements.2211.03271_929a654d11a8554f0fd7eaaa6270e: BC; in the previous year the archon at Athens was Socratides
elements.2211.03271_7eca21978f363faa2524172386bf6: This allows one to state explicitly that the earthquake was probably in December (or possibly in late November) 373
elements.2211.03271_d4ed13aacee85ed4a2765261ba8ce: BC rather than January or February 373

elements.2211.03271_7ca5a13806940ff85452be12175f1: I and II, or, more specifically, between the orbits of the Great March Comet of 1843 and the Great September Comet of 1882
elements.2211.03271_b9606be24bc14b1891e42a62ff3cd: it was suspected that the orbital motions of the sungrazers could have been affected differently by drag in the solar corona (e.g., Elkin 1883), which was thought might explain the gap
elements.2211.03271_064cd56268e02c42602ce6986342f: Besides, both the 1843 and 1880 sungrazers were measured only after perihelion
elements.2211.03271_3203825c28274d52a2cfe27676a88: The orbital gap was recognized as a serious problem once Kreutz (1891) found that the preperihelion observations of the single nucleus and the post-perihelion observations of the nuclear fragments of the 1882 sungrazer could readily be linked, ruling out a perceptible effect of the solar corona
elements.2211.03271_7b980a1ab8f3c1a10a1a003b80bb0: However, little was done until Marsden's (1967, 1989) thorough investigation of the orbital gap in terms of a long-term influence of the indirect planetary perturbations
elements.2211.03271_6e8d63589c2548c74cd7123eca453: Though ingenious, his method required highly nonrandom perturbations acting over long periods of time, a scenario that is contrary to evidence, as shown below.
elements.2211.03271_80e8738ffca8515b2128c39deaa27:
\begin{figure}[t]
\vspace{-8.13cm}
\hspace{1.73cm}
\centerline{
\scalebox{0.76}{
\includegraphics{f5_dwarf.ps}}} % FIGURE 5 = Figure 5 of Paper 2
\vspace{-7.22cm}
%
\caption{Schematic representation, at the time of breakup, of the Kreutz system's
parent (progenitor) nucleus, modeled as a rotating contact binary consisting of
Lobe~I, Lobe~II, and the connecting neck.  The view is from the direction of the
Sun and the position of the original orbital plane is defined by the parent's
pre-breakup orbital velocity vector {\boldmath $V_{\bf par}$}.  The dot in the
middle of the neck is the center of mass of the parent, coinciding with the
projected spin axis, which at aphelion is assumed to point at the Sun.  As a result
of the breakup, the lobes are subjected to orbital perturbations.  At the time of
breakup the comet rotates counterclockwise, so that Lobe~I is released to the lower
right, moving relative to the center of mass in the direction of the separation
velocity vector {\boldmath $V_{\bf sep}$}, while Lobe~II is released to the upper
left, moving in the direction of the separation velocity vector {\boldmath $-V_{\bf
sep}$}.  The separation velocity consists of its transverse, {\boldmath $V_{\bf T}$},
and normal, {\boldmath $V_{\bf N}$}, components, the radial one is assumed to be
\mbox{\boldmath $V_{\bf R}$ = 0}.  Summed up with the parent's pre-breakup
orbital-velocity vector, the separation velocities insert Lobe~I into a new orbit
defined by the velocity vector {\boldmath $V_{\bf I}$} and Lobe~II into an orbit
defined by the velocity vector {\boldmath $V_{\bf II}$}.  The Great March Comet
of 1843 is the largest surviving mass of Lobe~I, the Great September Comet of
1882 is the largest surviving mass of Lobe~II.  For clarity, the orbital and
separation velocities are not drawn to scale; in the scenario in Paper~1 the
ratio \mbox{{\boldmath $|V_{\bf sep}|$}/{\boldmath $|V_{\bf par}|$} = 0.13}.
(Reproduced from Paper~2.){\vspace{0.45cm}}}
\end{figure}
